Scheme 1 Suggested GVL formation mechanism starting from LA using Ru monometallic and Ni-Ru bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 GVL formation pathways [21]. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of parent γ-Al2O3, supported 1.9Pt/γ-Al2O3 and 1.8Ru/γ-Al2O3. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of parent γ-Al2O3, supported 0.5Ni-1.8Pt/γ-Al2O3 and 0.6Ni-1.9Ru/γ-Al2O3. Graphical abstract Hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) towards γ-valerolactone (GVL) is one of the most promising reactions in the field of biomass valorization to fine chemicals and liquid transportation fuels. Bimetallic Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were successfully utilized in this work as highly active and GVL-selective catalysts for the solvent-free hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) using formic acid (FA) as a hydrogen source in a microwave reactor, with results further translated into a continues flow system to prove the reaction mechanism. The supported bimetallic catalysts and their corresponding monometallic counterparts were characterized using N2-sorption, elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Under microwave irradiation, 100% selectivity to GVL was achieved using both mono- and bimetallic catalysts. Bimetallic Ni-Ru supported on γ-Al2O3 shows the highest LA conversion (71%) among the studied catalysts. This high activity is attributed to a larger Ru° concentration on the surface of γ-Al2O3 in comparison to ZrO2 as well as to the textural properties of γ-Al2O3 (i.e., surface acidity, specific surface area). In contrast, ZrO2‐based catalysts exhibited a higher stability with respect to γ-Al2O3-based after four consecutive runs of reaction. Keywords Levulinic acid conversion Microwaves Heterogeneous catalysis GVL Hydrogenation reactions 1 Introduction Global warming as well as distribution and availability of oil reservoirs around the world are major aspects limiting the large scale utilization of fossil fuels. These issues prompted scientists to seek alternative resources for the sustainable production of materials, chemicals and energy in order to protect the environment for the upcoming generations [1,2]. Biomass emerged as a highly promising feedstock to be converted into useful products due to its abundance, availability and various possibilities for a wide range of chemical transformations [3]. In particular, lignocellulosic feedstocks have recently been the subject of extensive studies as renewable and sustainable resources for production of hydrogen, chemicals and liquid transportation fuels [4–9]. Organic acids including levulinic (LA) and formic acid (FA) can be derived from lignocellulosics via acid-catalyzed hydrolysis processes [10–14]. LA has been utilized as a platform molecule for the production of valuable products including biofuels precursors such as γ-valerolactone (GVL), one of the most promising renewable platform chemicals for the production of liquid transportation fuels [15–17]. GVL has been produced from LA via catalytic hydrogenation to the unstable intermediate hydroxyvaleric acid (HVA) followed by ring closing and dehydration to GVL [18]. GVL was also obtained after hydrogenation of α-angelicalactone produced by dehydration of LA [19] as well as after dehydration of LA to the corresponding esters and followed by reduction steps (Fig. 1 ) [20,21]. Recently, the catalytic hydrogenation of LA in the presence of molecular hydrogen or FA as a hydrogen source using conventional batch and flow-type reactors has been extensively studied [22]. LA conversion was found to increase from 24% to 57% and from 48% to 100% by the addition of solid acid co-catalysts (i.e., ion exchange resins Amberlyst A70) to conventional Ru supported on γ-Al2O3 and C at 343K and 3MPa of H2 and 3h of reaction time, respectively [23]. Luo et al. [24] studied the effect of support acidity (i.e., Nb2O5, TiO2, H-ß, and H-ZSM5) and different solvents (i.e., Dioxane and 2-ethylhexanoic acid) in the hydrogenation of LA in a batch reactor using 4MPa of H2 at 473K, and 10h of reaction time. Supported Ru on TiO2 was found to exhibit an excellent catalytic performance (XLA =100% and SGVL =97.5%) using 2-ethylhexanoic acid as a solvent. The formation of Ru‐Pd nano-alloy on TiO2 also resulted in GVL-selective catalysts with superior activity (XLA >99% and SGVL =99.6%) and remarkable stability (over 3 catalytic cycles) in the hydrogenation of LA in dioxane at 4MPa of H2, 473K and 1600min−1 of stirring speed for 10h reaction time [25]. Alternatively, the Palkovits group reported full conversion of LA with selectivity of 97% to GVL after 50h of reaction time using Ru supported on carbon in a batch reactor using 1.2MPa of H2 at room temperature [26]. Yang et al. [27] reported a unique stability of homogenously dispersed Ru-Ni bimetallic nanoparticles (15 catalytic runs) onto an ordered mesoporous carbon; but it possessed a similar catalytic activity of monometallic Ru on ordered mesoporous carbon (i.e., XLA =99%) in neat LA hydrogenation at 4.5MPa of H2 and 423K. A high activity, selectivity and stability of a bimetallic Ru-Re/C in comparison to a conventional supported monometallic Ru on carbon for GVL production using a flow type reactor and FA as a hydrogen source (423K) was also demonstrated [28]. Interestingly, [Ru3(CO)12] was reported to be highly active and selective in the hydrogenation of LA under molecular H2 (i.e. 1.2MPa) or using a mixture of FA/Et3N as a hydrogen source at 403K and 24h of reaction time [29]. More recently, 92% LA conversion (>99% of GVL selectivity) could be achieved in toluene as the solvent using Ru nanoparticles on a basic support (i.e., Mg-LaO) at 353K and 0.5MPa after 4h of reaction [30]. Tan et al. [31] have also reported a complete LA conversion with 99.9% GVL selectivity in aqueous media using 1wt.-% Ru supported in TiO2 at 343K using 4MPa of H2 after 4h of reaction. In contrast to the hydrogenation of LA, the bimetallic catalysts containing noble and non‐noble metals (i.e., Ni-Ru, Ni-Pt, Ni-Au and Ni-Pd) supported on various support material (e.g., zeolite, ZrO2, γ-Al2O3 and SiO2) have been recently investigated in the upgrading of lignin‐derived compounds [32]. In particular, the combination of Ni-Ru shows higher activity and selectivity as compared to their single counterparts in the conversion of lignin to monomeric compounds [32]. Zhang et al. [33] demonstrated a high catalytic activity of the supported Ni-Ru, Ni-Rh and Ni-Pd in lignin hydrogenolysis and organosolv lignin at mild aqueous reaction conditions. Nevertheless, only few studies have thus far focused on the use of FA as a hydrogen source to replace the extensively employed high pressures of molecular hydrogen for the catalytic hydrogenation of LA. Comparatively, FA is concomitantly produced with LA from acid hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass, providing an additionally cheap, safe and highly efficient possibility for a one-pot hydroconversion of LA to valuable chemicals and biofuel precursors [34]. We have recently reported that LA can be converted into 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (MTHF) in good to excellent yields (ca. 60%) in the presence of FA employing Cu nanoparticles supported on SiO2 under continuous flow-type reaction conditions. Batch processes under microwave irradiation could achieve >90% conversion of LA with 75% selectivity to MTHF [35]. The combination of microwaves and FA as hydrogen source were then proved to be a sustainable and efficient partnership for LA conversion processes. In this work, we aimed to combine the previously demonstrated efficiency of microwave‐assisted reactions and the use of FA as a hydrogen source for the solvent-free and highly selective hydrogenation of LA to GVL. In addition, the reaction mechanism was further investigated under continuous flow conditions which pointed to the formation of HVA and its dehydrated analogue 3-pentenoic acid (3PA) on the acid sites of the support at short residence times. Solid catalysts based on bifunctional supported metal nanoparticles on commercial acidic supports (γ-Al2O3 and ZrO2) were designed to maximize the conversion and selectivity in the systems at short reaction times (typically 60–90min). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Levulinic acid (LA) (≥98%), formic acid (FA) (≥95%), acetonitrile (99.8%), ethyl acetate (≥99%) and ruthenium(III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3·xH2O) (99.98%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. The parent support materials (i.e., ZrO2, γ-Al2O3), tetraammine platinum(II) nitrate (Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2) (99.99%) and nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) (99.99%) were supplied by Alfa Aesar. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Supported monometallic (i.e., Pt and Ru) and bimetallic (i.e., Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru) catalysts supported on ZrO2 or γ-Al2O3 were synthesized using sequential incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). The supported monometallic catalysts were prepared with 2.0wt.-% as a theoretical loading. The supported bimetallic catalysts (i.e.,Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru) on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were prepared with (1:1) as molar ratio with 2.0wt.-% calculated loading of Pt and Ru. For supported monometallic catalysts, tetraammine platinum(II) nitrate and ruthenium(III) chloride hydrate were dissolved separately in deionized water and added dropwise to the parent support materials (i.e., ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3). The supported Pt and Ru catalysts were dried in air at 373K for 12h. The supported bimetallic catalysts were prepared by impregnation of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate solution on the dried supported Pt and Ru catalysts, respectively. Then, the supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts were dried at 373K for 12h and calcined for 4h at 723K in air. Prior to the catalytic experiments, all supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts were reduced at 623K under a flow of H2 (2.0cm3 min−1) in N2 (8.0cm3 min−1) for 6h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The density of the acid sites of the parent supports (i.e., γ-Al2O3 and ZrO2) was quantified by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3). The calcined mono- and bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were characterized by N2-sorption, elemental analysis (ICP-OES), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The TPD-NH3 was performed using a U-type quartz glass microreactor. The evolved gases were analyzed with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer GSD 301). Prior to the analysis, the catalyst was pretreated in He (30.0cm3 min−1) at 523K for 1h. After cooling to 368K, six consecutive pulses of NH3 (1.0cm3 for each pulse) were employed to reach complete saturation adsorption on the surface of catalyst. After the removal of physisorbed NH3 by purging with He, the sample was heated from 368K to 873K (heating ramp of 10Kmin−1) in flowing He (50.0cm3 min−1) while analyzing the desorbed NH3 by MS (m/e=16). The amount of desorbed ammonia was quantified using a reference test (i.e., pulsing 1.0ml of NH3 over 50.0mg of inert quartz. A micromeritics ASAP2010-Physisorption Analyzer was utilized to record the N2-sorption isotherms for calcined and spent catalysts. All the samples were evacuated at 523K under the vacuum pressure of 3·10−11 MPa for 6h before measurements and the isotherms were taken at 77K. The specific surface area (ABET) was determined by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model. The specific pore volume (Vp) was estimated from N2 uptake at a p/p0 value of 0.99. The pore width distribution (dp) were deduced from the desorption branch using Barrett- Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The metal content was determined optical emission spectrometry by inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES). The procedure includes dissolution of the ZrO2-based samples in aqueous HF/HNO3/HCl/H2SO4/H3PO4 media. Also, the γ-Al2O3-based catalyst was digested in aqueous HF/HNO3/HCl solution using a Philips PU 70 000 sequential spectrometer equipped with an Echelle monochromator (0.0075nm resolution) coupled with mass spectrometry. XRD patterns for all calcined mono- and bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were recorded at room temperature using a Siemens, D5000 diffractometer. The diffracted intensity of Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.154nm) was measured at the range of 2θ between 4.0° and 90.0°, with a step size of 0.02° and a counting time of 0.2s for phase identification. XPS measurements were conducted at an ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) multipurpose surface analysis system (Specs™ model, Germany) operating at pressures <10−14 MPa using a conventional X-Ray source (XR-50, Specs, Mg-Kα, 1253.6eV) in a “stop-and-go” mode to reduce potential damage due to sample irradiation. The survey and detailed Fe and Cu high-resolution spectra (pass energy 25.0 and 10.0eV, step size 1 and 0.1eV, respectively) were recorded at room temperature using a Phoibos 150-MCD energy analyser. Powdered samples were deposited on a sample holder using double sided adhesive tape and subsequently evacuated under vacuum (<10−6 Torr) overnight. Eventually, the sample holder containing the degassed sample was transferred to the analysis chamber for XPS studies. Binding energies were referenced to the C1s line at 284.6eV from adventitious carbon. TEM images for selected calcined mono- and bimetallic supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts were recorded using Philips CM100 Transmission Electron Microscope operated at 100kV and equipped with TENGRA 2.3K×2.3K camera for digital imaging. 2.4 Catalytic experiments The catalytic hydrogenation of LA towards GVL was performed using a stirred focalized microwave reactor supplied by CEM-Discover. In a typical experiment, 0.05cm3 of LA and 0.30cm3 of FA and 0.1g of catalyst were introduced to a 10.0cm3 glass tube and irradiated by 300W of microwaves at 423K for 90min under autogenic pressure with continuous stirring. For quantitative analysis of the reaction mixture, the reaction mixture was diluted by addition of 2.0cm3 of acetonitrile. 0.3μl of the diluted mixture were then injected into a GC instrument (Hewlett Packard HP5890 Series II) equipped with a (28047-U SUPELCO Equity®-1) column (60m×0.25mm×0.25μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The temperature program was set as follows: the initial temperature (363K) was kept constant for 6min. Then, it was gradually increased to the final temperature (443K) with a ramp of 20Kmin−1 and maintained for 21min. In order to investigate the stability of the catalysts, after each run the catalysts were filtrated, washed, dried at 373K for 12h and used again in the reaction. The conventional batch catalytic hydrogenation of LA to GVL was performed in 50.0cm3 PTFE-coated stainless steel autoclave (SUS-316, TAIATSU TECHNO) with an external temperature and pressure controller (BERGHOF, Model # BTC − 3000). The catalytic experiments were conducted using 0.5cm3 of LA and 3.0cm3 of FA and 1.0g of catalyst at 423K for 90min under autogenic pressure. Then, reaction mixture was diluted by addition of 2.0cm3 of acetonitrile. 0.5μl of the diluted mixture were then injected into a GC instrument (Shimadzu GC-14A) equipped with a (HP-FFAP) column (50m×0.32mm×0.50μm) and FID. The temperature program was set as follows: the initial temperature (313K) was kept constant for 1min. Then, it was elevated to (383K) with a ramp of 20Kmin−1 and maintained for 5min. Then, it was gradually increased to the final temperature (513K) with a ramp of 20Kmin−1 and maintained for 15min. Continuous flow experiments were carried out in a H-Cube mini instrument from Thalesnano [36] equipped with a back pressure regulator and a water electrolysis module for hydrogen generation. In a typical experiment, 0.1g of the catalyst were packed in a cartridge and introduced into the catcart holder of the instrument where a flow of LA (0.2M solution in ethyl acetate) was pumped through at 0.30cm3 min−1 at 363K, 5.0MPa of hydrogen pressure. Experiments were run for 20min and fractions were collected every 5min. A careful control of reaction temperature and flow allowed us to follow the course of the reaction and the intermediates generated at different times were analyzed in a similar way to samples obtained from microwave experiments (see above). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization N2-physisorption has been utilized in order to characterize the textural properties of calcined supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts. According to the IUPAC classification, all prepared and calcined mono- and bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 exhibited isotherms type IV, characteristic of mesoporous materials with hysteresis loop of type H1 (narrow pore width distribution). BJH calculations of the aforementioned catalysts indicated a narrow pore width distribution in a range of 7.5nm to 10.0nm. The isotherms and pore width distribution for all supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts are depicted in Fig. S1, ESI. Textural properties, i.e., specific surface area (ABET), specific pore volume (Vp) and pore width (dp) of the parent support and calcined mono- and bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 are shown in Table 1 and compiled in the ESI. No significant changes in specific pore volume (Vp) and pore width (dp) were observed upon metal impregnation, drying and calcination in comparison with the corresponding parent support materials for all supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts. An expected minor decrease in specific surface area was observed in all cases caused by the partial deposition of metal oxide and metal nanoparticles on the surface of the support. Ni, Pt and Ru loadings on the supports were determined by elemental analysis via ICP (Table 1) for all supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts. The supported monometallic catalysts (i.e., Pt and Ru) were prepared with a 2.0wt.-% aimed metal loading as compared to bimetallic (i.e., Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru) on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 which were comparably synthesized under a (1:1) as molar ratio with a 2.0wt.-% aimed final loading of Pt and Ru. Actual metal loadings were slightly lower to aimed loadings of Ni, Pt and Ru in all cases except for 2.1Pt/ZrO2. These observed reduced loadings can be attributed to loss of precursors during impregnation, drying and/or calcination steps. The inhomogeneous impregnation of metal precursors on the support materials can be another reason for the observed differences in metal loadings. The crystallinity of all calcined supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were investigated using XRD. XRD patterns for supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts on γ‐Al2O3 are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 , respectively. 1.8Ru/γ-Al2O3 characteristic diffraction lines at 2θ=27.8°, 35.0° and 54.0° can be assigned to RuO2. In the case of 0.6Ni-1.9Ru/γ-Al2O3, three more characteristic lines for RuO2 at 2θ=58.0°, 59.5° and 69.6° in addition to the aforementioned RuO2 reflexes were observed. In contrast, no distinct diffraction lines for Ni were observed most probably due to low Ni content on the supports (0.5–0.6wt.-% determined by ICP-OES) and their high dispersion/low crystallinity on the support. No characteristic diffraction lines for Ni, Pt and Ru were detected in the supported bimetallic (i.e., Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru) and the corresponding monometallic catalysts on ZrO2 (see also Fig. S13 and S14 at ESI). This can be explained by overlapping of the distinct diffraction lines of Ni, Pt and Ru with the lines of the monoclinic ZrO2 phase. In order to determine Ni, Pt and Ru nanoparticle sizes, TEM and HR-TEM images for selected supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts were recorded. TEM images for 2.1Pt/ZrO2, 0.5Ni‐1.8Pt/γ-Al2O3, 0.6Ni-1.9Pt/ZrO2, 0.6Ni-1.7Ru/ZrO2 and 0.6Ni-1.9Ru/γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 4 (A, B, C, D and E), respectively. TEM images of 2·1Pt/ZrO2 (Fig. 4A and B) clearly illustrate the presence of well dispersed ZrO2 nanoparticles (particle sizes in the range 5.0–10.0nm) homogeneous in size and shape with no clear presence of supported Pt nanoparticles as shown in the inset of an individual nanoparticle for 0.6Ni-1.9Pt/ZrO2. High-resolution TEM shows that the clear interplanar distance is 0.510nm which corresponds to the {100} plane of monoclinic ZrO2 (Fig. 4C). Interestingly, the quasi‐spherical morphology and homogeneous distribution of nanoparticles for ZrO2 (with no clear presence of Pt or Ni nanoparticles) was very different from the observed nanofibrillar structure of γ-Al2O3 0.5Ni-1.8Pt/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 4E) in which some nanoparticles of different sizes imaged as black spots (<5.0nm) can be clearly seen. In contrast, the supported 0.6Ni-1.9Ru on γ-Al2O3 exhibit a heterogeneous distribution of Ni and Ru nanoparticles (an average particle size of ca. 30.0nm) with some larger aggregates present (Fig. 4F and G). XPS spectra were additionally recorded for all fresh prepared mono- and bimetallic catalysts. C1s lines were calibrated at 284.6eV for all samples. XPS spectra of Ru 3d and Pt 4f for supported bimetallic Ni-Ru and Ni-Pt on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 5 (A, B, C and D), respectively. Ni 2p, O1s, Zr 3d and Al 2p XPS spectra are given in Figs. S9 to 12, ESI. Higher concentrations of Ru° and Pt° were always observed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 materials as compared to ZrO2-based catalyst (Table 2 ). Only the evaluation of Ru metallic state were possible due to the overlapping of Ru 3d3/2 and Run+ 3d5/2 bands with C1s signals. Zhen et al. [37] have reported that the Ru° peak appeared at 280.1eV using similar support material (i.e., γ‐Al2O3). In the case of supported Ni-Ru on ZrO2, no difference in recorded binding energies for Ru° were observed as compared to a negative shift of Ru° (−0.9eV) for Ni-Ru on γ-Al2O3. These findings point at a weaker interaction between Ru° and γ-Al2O3, in good agreement with previous results for Ru-containing materials [39]. 3.2 Levulinic acid hydrogenation The catalytic hydrogenation of LA using FA as a hydrogen source was performed over mono‐ and bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3. LA conversion (XLA) and GVL selectivity (SGVL) results using supported Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru bimetallic and their corresponding monometallic counterparts on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 as catalysts are depicted in Figs. 6 and 7 , respectively. A complete selectivity (100%) towards GVL was achieved using all tested supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts under the investigated conditions, although an interesting selectivity to 3-pentenoic acid was observed at short times of reaction (<15min) which may point to a particularly favored reaction pathway in GVL production as discussed later on. Monometallic Ru on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts were comparatively more active (XLA =30% and 50%) to monometallic Pt over the same support materials (XLA =22% and 42%). Importantly, 0.6Ni-1.9Ru on γ-Al2O3 exhibits the highest catalytic activity (XLA =71%) among the tested catalysts. It is noteworthy that Ni-Ru bimetallic systems on both support materials (i.e., ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3) provide a higher catalytic activity (XLA =38% and 71%) with respect to Ni-Pt bimetallic systems on the same support material (XLA =28% and 55%). This high activity of supported Ni-Ru on γ-Al2O3 can be explained by the higher amount of Ru° species on the surface of the support. In addition, the weak interaction between Ru species and the support in γ-Al2O3 observed in XPS studies could also favour the activation of Ru active sites in the hydroconversion of LA. γ-Al2O3-based catalysts generally exhibited higher catalytic activity as compared to ZrO2-based catalysts. This behaviour can also be attributed to the textural and surface acid properties of γ-Al2O3, namely a high specific surface area (284m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.7cm3 g−1) as well as a higher density of acid sites (25.3μmolg−1) in comparison to ZrO2 (4.8μmolg−1). For comparative purposes, identically performed reactions (i.e., LA+FA) using analogous catalyst/substrate ratios (see experimental section) were conducted in a conventional batch reactor using bimetallic Ni-Ru supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3. LA conversion (XLA) and GVL selectivity (SGVL) results using bimetallic Ni-Ru supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 in conventional batch reactor are illustrated in Figs. 6 and 7 Almost negligible LA conversion (i.e., 2.5% and 3.8%) was obtained under identical conventional batch reactor conditions (to those of microwave experiments) using 0.6Ni-1.7Ru/ZrO2 and 0.6Ni-1.9Ru/γ-Al2O3, respectively. These results obtained under conventional batch reactor conditions can be attributed to a low H2 pressure (i.e. 0.2MPa) generated due to decomposition of FA in the conventional batch reactor in comparison to high pressures recorded under microwave-assisted conditions (2.0MPa). Furthermore, differences in the head space of the reactor and the heat distribution as well scaling up the reactant volume and the catalysts mass can not be excluded. The highest active catalysts under the microwave conditions i.e., monometallic Ru and bimetallic Ni-Ru catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were selected to perform the hydrogenation of LA under continuous flow conditions. All catalytic experiments were subsequently conducted under continuous flow conditions. Results included in Table 3 pointed to a high selectivity of 3PA (derived from HVA- via LA dehydration) at short times-on-stream, which indicated the reaction may proceed as suggested in Scheme 1 . LA was hydrogenated on the active metal sites to HVA which further dehydrated to 3PA and eventually undergoes to ring closing step and transformed to GVL. Interestingly, only traces of pentenoic acid could be detected using previously reported Pd systems [35,38,39]. Moreover, the commercial Pd/C catalyst utilized for comparative purposes in this work exhibited a low selectivity towards GVL in comparison to monometallic Ru and Ni‐Ru bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 prepared in this work (Table 3). This observation points to the possibility of a different reaction pathway of Ru and Ru‐Ni catalysts as compared to the aforementioned Pd systems or the commercial Pd/C catalyst. Catalytic experiments also provided a generally low catalytic activity (<35%) in the continuous flow systems as compared to conversions observed under microwave irradiation. Nevertheless, the optimum catalytic system 0.6Ni-1.9Ru/γ-Al2O3 was able to provide a ca. 35% conversion after 20min of reaction under continuous flow conditions, with a complete selectivity to GVL. A high selectivity to 3PA was also observed at short residence times (typically less than 10min). The reaction pathway suggested in this work (Scheme 1) is in line with the observations of Abdelrahman et al. [22] who correlated the presence of H2 in the systems with a mechanism proceeding to GVL only via HPA. Furthermore, the acid-catalyzed intramolecular esterification (ring closure) of HPA to GVL was reported as rate limiting step at comparable reaction temperatures to those utilised in this work [22]. Higher reaction temperatures favoured this step, with LA hydrogenation being proposed as rate limiting step based on mass transfer considerations [22]. These results were in good agreement with the discussed microwave-assisted experiments which also seem to indicate a similar reaction mechanism under microwave irradiation and continuous flow conditions despite the differences in reaction conditions (i.e., the use of formic acid as hydrogen source and molecular hydrogen as hydrogenating agent, respectively). Reactions performed at longer residence times did not significantly improve the conversion in the systems. Despite the high hydrogen pressures, the relatively low temperatures (363K and below) employed in the H-Cube mini system account for such low activities which again demonstrated the potential of the proposed microwave-assisted methodology in this work. 3.3 Catalyst stability The stability of the supported Ni-Ru on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 which exhibit an optimum catalytic activity among the tested catalysts (71% conversion, 100% selectivity to GVL) was subsequently assessed after four consecutive catalytic runs (Fig. 8 ). GVL selectivity remained unchanged after several re-uses of the above mentioned catalysts (Fig. S15 in ESI). Interestingly, the initial catalytic activity of 0.6Ni-1.7Ru on ZrO2 was essentially preserved without any remarkable loss in activity after four subsequent runs. This behaviour can be simply explained after a thorough characterisation of the reused catalyst which exhibited a reduction in porosity after four consecutive reaction runs. The structure of the nanocatalyst was also preserved as indicated by XRD (Fig. S16, ESI), with an almost negligible leaching (<5ppm metal) of the active metal phase into the reaction mixture. In contrast, a dissapointing and significant decrease in LA conversion (i.e., from 71% to 31%) was obtained for 0.6Ni-1.9Ru on γ-Al2O3 after the second use of the catalyst. Fig. 8 clearly illustrates that the catalyst continues deactivating after the third consecutive run. The observed drop in activity after reuses can be correlated to a remarkable loss in specific surface area (from 259 to 53m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.7 to 0.2cm3 g−1) as well as a gradual phase transformation of γ-Al2O3 to a boehmite phase (AlOOH) after four consequtive runs (see compared XRD patterns, Fig. S17 in ESI). Furthermore, nanoparticle sintering and leaching of the metal phase might also account for the observed catalyst deactivation [40]. Although none of these were specifically observed in TEM (no significant sintering) of the reused catalysts. Additionally, oxidation of the metal species (i.e., Ni and Ru) after four consecutive catalytic experiments may also lead to catalyst deactivation phenomenon. 4 Conclusions Bimetallic Ni-Ru catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 were found to be highly active and selective in the microwave-assisted solvent-free in-situ hydrogenation of LA to GVL in the presence of FA as a hydrogen source. Catalyst characterization indicated that the catalytic performance was highly dependent on the metals distribution on the surface and textural/surface acid properties of the support material. Significant differences in activities between supported bimetallic (i.e., Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru) and their corresponding monometallic catalysts were observed. Insights into the reaction mechanism indicated the formation of 3PA as intermediate with a particular proposed mechanism which seems to be in good agreement between microwave-assisted and continuous flow reactions using different hydrotreating protocols. These results are envisaged to pave the way in the design of advanced Ni-Ru catalysts for biomass valorisation to fine chemicals and liquid transportation fuels. More detailed spectroscopic investigations on the interaction between the metal phase and the support materials as well as on the long term stability as currently ongoing in our laboratories will provide additional insights to further improve these most active and selective catalysts for advanced biomass conversion technologies. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) towards γ-valerolactone (GVL) is one of the most promising reactions in the field of biomass valorization to fine chemicals and liquid transportation fuels. Bimetallic Ni-Pt and Ni-Ru supported on ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3 were successfully utilized in this work as highly active and GVL-selective catalysts for the solvent-free hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) using formic acid (FA) as a hydrogen source in a microwave reactor, with results further translated into a continues flow system to prove the reaction mechanism. The supported bimetallic catalysts and their corresponding monometallic counterparts were characterized using N2-sorption, elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Under microwave irradiation, 100% selectivity to GVL was achieved using both mono- and bimetallic catalysts. Bimetallic Ni-Ru supported on γ-Al2O3 shows the highest LA conversion (71%) among the studied catalysts. This high activity is attributed to a larger Ru° concentration on the surface of γ-Al2O3 in comparison to ZrO2 as well as to the textural properties of γ-Al2O3 (i.e., surface acidity, specific surface area). In contrast, ZrO2‐based catalysts exhibited a higher stability with respect to γ-Al2O3-based after four consecutive runs of reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone using supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts
